Literature Review: The field of virology has been revolutionized by the discovery of biomolecular condensates and their role in viral replication and assembly. This literature review explores the current understanding of phase separation in viral processes, with a focus on viruses containing segmented RNA genomes, and draws parallels with cellular RNA-rich condensates.Biomolecular condensates are membrane-less organelles that form through liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of proteins and nucleic acids. These condensates play crucial roles in various cellular processes, including RNA metabolism, stress response, and signal transduction. In recent years, researchers have recognized the importance of phase separation in viral replication and assembly, particularly in the formation of viral factories or inclusions.Viral factories are specialized compartments within infected cells where viral genome replication and particle assembly occur. These structures have been observed in various virus families, including rotaviruses, reoviruses, and influenza viruses. Nikolic et al. (2017) demonstrated that rotavirus NSP5 protein undergoes LLPS to form liquid-like droplets in vitro and in cells, which serve as precursors for viral factories called viroplasms. This study highlighted the importance of protein-protein interactions and intrinsically disordered regions in driving phase separation of viral components.The formation of viral factories through phase separation offers several advantages for virus replication. Guseva et al. (2020) proposed that condensates create a favorable microenvironment for viral processes by concentrating viral components and excluding host factors that may interfere with replication. Additionally, the liquid-like nature of these condensates allows for rapid exchange of molecules and efficient assembly of viral particles.Interestingly, the hierarchical coassembly of viral RNAs and proteins within viral factories bears striking similarities to the organization of cellular RNA-rich condensates, such as the nucleolus. Feric et al. (2016) demonstrated that the nucleolus forms through a multiphase liquid-liquid phase separation process, driven by the differential solubility of its components. Similarly, Borodavka et al. (2018) showed that rotavirus genome segment assortment relies on a hierarchical RNA-RNA interaction network, which may be facilitated by phase separation within viroplasms.The role of RNA in driving phase separation has been extensively studied in cellular contexts, and these findings have informed our understanding of viral condensates. Langdon et al. (2018) revealed that long noncoding RNAs can act as scaffolds for the assembly of membrane-less organelles, while Maharana et al. (2018) demonstrated that RNA can modulate the phase behavior of RNA-binding proteins. In the context of viruses, Patel et al. (2015) showed that the genomic RNA of vesicular stomatitis virus acts as a multivalent scaffold for the assembly of replication complexes, suggesting a similar role for viral RNAs in organizing phase-separated compartments.The formation and regulation of viral condensates are influenced by various factors, including protein concentration, RNA-protein interactions, and post-translational modifications. Brangwynne et al. (2015) proposed that cells can control phase separation through 'compositional control' by regulating the concentration and interactions of condensate components. This concept has been applied to viral systems, where the expression levels of viral proteins and the availability of genomic RNA segments can modulate the formation and properties of viral factories.Post-translational modifications have emerged as important regulators of biomolecular condensates. Aumiller et al. (2016) demonstrated that phosphorylation can tune the phase separation behavior of proteins by altering their charge and interactions. In the context of viruses, Criglar et al. (2018) showed that phosphorylation of rotavirus NSP5 protein is crucial for the formation and maturation of viroplasms, highlighting the importance of post-translational modifications in viral factory assembly.The study of phase separation in viral processes has opened up new avenues for antiviral strategies. Gao et al. (2019) proposed that targeting the phase separation properties of viral proteins could disrupt the formation of replication compartments and inhibit virus production. This approach represents a novel paradigm in antiviral drug development, focusing on the biophysical properties of viral components rather than traditional enzymatic targets.As our understanding of biomolecular condensates in viral replication continues to grow, several areas for future research emerge. One important direction is the development of advanced imaging techniques to visualize the dynamics of phase separation in infected cells. Additionally, further investigation into the molecular determinants of viral condensate formation and the role of host factors in this process will provide valuable insights into virus-host interactions.In conclusion, the study of biomolecular condensates has provided a new lens through which to view viral replication and assembly. By drawing parallels between cellular RNA-rich condensates and viral factories, researchers have uncovered common principles governing the organization of these complex biological systems. As this field continues to evolve, it promises to reshape our understanding of virus biology and open up new possibilities for antiviral interventions.
